entry.title: Re: 429 Too many requests error on SAP Commerce CLouds
entry.content:
The rate limit feature is available on the endpoint level and can be configured in four level:

  • No limit: there is no limit to active open connections. This was the default configuration before the implementation of WAF in SAP Commerce Cloud.
  • Small: threshold of 50 requests, five-second cooldown.
  • Medium: threshold of 500 requests, five-second cooldown.
  • Large: threshold of 5000 requests, five-second cooldown.

You can know more about this using KBA 3403719 - HTTP 429 Too Many Requests - SAP Commerce Cloud

entry.title: Re: Rework Process in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (P...
entry.content:
Hi @MohamedKharbouch 

Thank you for your question.

Consider consulting Manufacturing, Rework Processing ‚Äì Stock-Manufactured Material (BJN), Manage Process Order Operations & Process Order Confirmation Object Page for more details.

To summarise, based on the details you provided, a reworks scenario like you described can be done with a dedicated rework recipe and process order.

  • First is to model a rework recipe in the manage recipes app, where the nonconforming FG is the input and the conforming FG, co-products and scrap are the outputs.
  • Then you should create a rework process order in the manage process order app, making sure you reference the rework recipe.
  • During the order confirmation, ensure you issue the nonconforming FG as input and record receipts of conforming FG as input and record receipts of conforming FG, co-products and scrap.

Please note that costs will then be collected on the rework order and can be settled accordingly.

This approach I mentioned above will ensure transparency of materials flows; it will help you correct cost allocation and traceability in line with process industry best practices.

Should you often carry out rework, consider maintaining a dedicated order type for rework to distinguish it from standard production.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud: Outbound Del. and Inspection Lot in...
entry.content:
Hello @AM1987 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at KBA 2805020, Quality Certificates, Manage Certifications & Quality certificate for Delivery for more details.

However, the summary is, the quality certificate generation is plant-dependent in public cloud. The inspection lot and the outbound delivery must belong to the same plant for the system to pull the results and generate the certificate.

If you inspection lot exists in a different plant, the certificate cannot be automatically retrieved in the delivery process, therefore aligning with the systems standard behaviour in public cloud.

You have the options to:

  • Ensure that the inspection lot is created in the shipping plant
  • Alternatively, you can generate the quality certificate directly from the inspection lot plant and then attach it manually to the outbound delivery document.

I hope this provides the desired insight.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: unable to create Stories in sap public cloud(3SL)
entry.content:
Hello @Thanushree1999 

Thank you for your question.

Have a looked at Manage KPIs and Reports & Analytics in Cloud for more details.

To summarise based on the details and the screenshot provided, the error you are experiencing indicates a missing role or inactive analytics account. There are a few things to evaluate:

  • Ensure your user has the analytics specialist role assigned.
  • Verify that the business role includes catalogs such as SAP_CORE_BC_EXT_KPI which helps Manage KPIs and Reports or SAP_CORE_BC_EXT_STORY which focuses on Story Design
  • Confirm that your business user is active and linked correctly in the manage workforce.
  • If your roles are correct but the issue persists, reach out to your administrator to check your embedded SAC provisioning because if you design stories, you must also have an active SAC account.

I hope this provides the desired insight.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Error eDocument Cockpit
entry.content:
Hello @JordanoJ 

Thank you for your question.

Have a looked at Submitting Electronic Documents, eDocument Cockpit for more details.

To summarise, the situation you described is common when you integrate eDocument cockpit with external e-invoicing provider through the integration suite. From your description the iFlow is executed successfully. The error you are experiencing indicates a destination configuration issue on the cloud side.

  • First thing to check is to ensue the outbound service is assigned and points correctly to your integration suite endpoint.
  • Your communication system linked to SAP_COM_0521 has the correct host, authentication method and user.
  • If your iFlow process and finishes but does not map back the response to S4, the cockpit will flag it as an error. You may need to adapt iFlow to send back a proper status in the expected format.

If everything is configured, then make sure you clear and retry the document in eDocument cockpit.

I hope this provides the desired insight.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud: Quality Certificate doesn't print t...
entry.content:
Hello @AM1987 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at Quality Certificates, Manage Quality Certificates for Inspection Lots, KBA 2805020 & Record Inspection Results for more details.

To summarise, your set up in CBS by creating a new result origin (Y1) and assigning it in the certificate profile is the correct approach. However, for your certificate to print the mean value of all inspection points you must ensure you meet the public cloud requirements.

  • You must define the master inspection characteristic for summarised recording.
  • Second, in the record inspection results, you must ensure that a summarised result is calculated and saved for the inspection lot.
  • Final step as you have already done is to is to assign in the certificate profile the result selection level to summarised result origin= Y1.

If these settings are correct, the system will pull the mean value across all inspection points into the quality certificate. However, if only the last value is printed, then that usually mans that the MIC or the inspection is still set to single result recording or summarised values were not maintained in the inspection lot.

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/quality-certificate-for-delivery/qaq-p/5613580

I hope this provides the desired insight.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: India TDS Recipient type in Business partner master data
entry.content:
--Cause--

Standard behavior: We can use SSCUI 103127 - Define Account Groups with Screen Layout (Supplier) to make the field "TDS Recipient Type" mandatory.

--Solution--

The path:

  1. Open SSCUI 103127 - Define Account Groups with Screen Layout (Supplier).
  2. Select the Supplier.
  3. Select the Company Code Data.
  4. Select the Withholding Tax Data.
  5. Select "Withholding tax category, w/h tax 2" and change it to "required" for the second one.

entry.title: Re: Service Entry Sheet by value
entry.content:
Hi @lmarellano 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at Service Procurement & Create Service Entry Sheet for more details.

To summarise, the standard service entry receipts in public cloud are quantity driven. When you create a PO with a fixed quantity and price, the system expects you to post receipts as percentages or partial quantities. The system then calculates the corresponding amounts which explains the rounding issues you are seeing. If your requirement is to post service receipts directly by amount, then you should use a limit-based service PO.

  • When you create PO, ensure you maintain an overall limit in the limits section instead of specifying a fixed quantity.
  • When you create a service entry sheet against this PO, you can then enter the exact amount for each service point.
  • The system consumes against the limit amount rather than distributing based on quantities or percentages.

I hope this provides the desired insight.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Custom CDS - Modification After Publishing - S4 Publi...
entry.content:
Hello @SamHilton 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at  SAP Note 2587346,  Custom CDS Views & Building Custom Solutions by Extending CDS Views on SAP S/4HANA Cloud

The summary is, CDS views are handled differently in public cloud compared to on-premise or private cloud.

To prevent inconsistencies, you cannot directly change the join conditions of a base CDS view if it is referenced by other CDS views.

You are recommended to create a new CDS view with the modified join conditions and then adjust dependent CDS views to point to this new view.

Since direct editing is not possible, CDS extensibility must be done using the custom CDS views app. Eclipse development is on available for on-premise, private cloud systems or on BTP.

I hope this provides the desired insight.

Best regards

Chris

entry.content:
To store Golden Tax invoice numbers in financial documents, the SGTXT field can be utilized through BAdI implementation.

For the app Create Golden Tax Documents - China, use BAdI ID: IDGTCN_OB_OPR_AFT_FETCH_INVC (China: Operations After Fetching VAT Invoices).

For the app Create Outbound Files - China, employ BAdI ID: IDGTCN_WRITEBACK_CLOUD.

entry.title: Re: Date of Last Sales Order
entry.content:
Hello MarisaF-UPI,

In the standard report, i.e. Sales Order Volume report, it is possible to filter by account, and show the sales orders as well as their calendar day (posting date in the order). You are able to set filter on the order, but not able to set formular or condition to show only the last sales order.  You can export the report and set sorting based on sales order ID, to get the last sales order and its posing date.

Alternatively, you may check in the account master data, in Sales tab, it shows you all the sales history created for this account. 

  • Set filter as Sales Order in Doc.Type, 
  • Set sorting in the Document Item ID

Then you will get the posting date.

Thanks,

Adie

entry.title: Re: S4H public cloud - Custom CDSView External API for cr...
entry.content:
Yes, create and update operations are possible for custom External APIs, but with important distinctions based on the type of custom object you're working with.

For Custom Business Objects (CBOs)

Full CRUD operations are supported for Custom Business Objects. This includes:

  • Create - Add new business object instances
  • Read - Query existing data
  • Update - Modify existing instances
  • Delete - Remove instances

You can also use batch operations to load datasets in a single API call, which is particularly useful for bulk data operations.

For updating Custom Business Objects via External API, refer to the SAP Help documentation on "Updating Business Object Instances with an OData Request".

For Custom CDS Views

Custom CDS Views created for External API scenarios are read-only. The External API scenario for Custom CDS Views only supports:

  • Read operations - Data retrieval and querying
  • View/Browse functionality - Displaying data in browsers

Create, update, and delete operations are not supported for Custom CDS Views exposed as External APIs.

entry.title: Re: How to Implement Triangular Trade Intercompany Busine...
entry.content:
Below is the business process for this scenarios :

The German company sells to the customer and the US company delivers (i.e. the US plant is still the delivering plant in SO2), but the German company does this by buying the goods from the French company. This company in turns buys the goods from the US company: a purchase order towards the French company is automatically created when SO2 is saved, leading to a sales order in France (SO4') and an additional purchase order from the French company towards the US (PO3'), which created SO4.

A multi level process using a single SAP S/4HANA system is also planned to be available. One or more intermediate companies can be included in the process, where for example the German company still determines the US plant as the delivering plant but where the ordering is done via the French company (PO3 leading to SO4' in the figure), that in turn orders the goods from the delivering company in the US (PO3' and SO4).

Currently ,only workaround solution could be used .

Single SO+Advanced intercompany 

Please wait for the further update.

Thanks

entry.title: Re: React BTP app throwing 403 token validation failed when teying post to backend
entry.content: The 403 Forbidden error during your React app's POST call from BTP to S/4 is likely due to an issue with the session, not the token itself. While you've correctly disabled approuter CSRF protection, the backend still requires a valid session to validate the token. Check your browser's network tab to confirm that the Set-Cookie header from the initial token fetch is being sent back as a Cookie header with your POST request. Ensure your frontend fetch logic includes credentials: 'include' to handle cookies. Also, verify that the destination user in BTP has the correct permissions for the POST operation in the S/4 backend, as this can also lead to a generic 403 error.

entry.title: Re: Contract and Lease Management Migration in SAP Public...
entry.content:
Hello @charlene2 

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, migrating legacy CLM contracts as technical objects is generally not advisable.

Below are the recommended approaches

The first prerequisites for migration include Business Partners, real estate objects, and organisational data, accessible via Migrate Your Data ‚Äì Migration Cockpit. SAP Help Portal-Data Migration

Re-establish active Lease-In and Lease-Out contracts in the new CLM system, including opening balances and obligations for IFRS and US-GAAP. Contract valuation rules are not configured in the cockpit and must be established within the application.SAP Help-Implementing Contract and Lease Management in an SAP S/4HANA Cloud System 

Use the provided scope items: Lease-In Accounting 1T6 and the Lease-Out scope items, as your process baseline and test cases. SAP Help-Contract and Lease Management

Check the SAP KBA Valuations following the bulk imports cockpit; SAP Support Portal-3562443 - Contract and Lease Management: How to perform valuations after mass imports

Let me know if you need further information

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: How Personal Spending Habits Mirror Enterprise Procurement
entry.content:
Introduction

When it comes to managing our personal finances, most of us intuitively follow certain steps to control spending and save more. Interestingly, these same steps closely mirror the structured procurement processes that enterprises use to manage spend at scale.

To illustrate, let‚Äôs start with a simple personal example and then see how it aligns with enterprise procurement practices.

Personal Spend and Saving: A Simple Thought Process

Imagine you want to save more money this month. You realize there are two main ways to do that:

  1. Increase your income.       ‚¨ÜÔ∏è
  2. Reduce your expenses.     ‚¨áÔ∏è

Let‚Äôs focus on reducing expenses.

This logical sequence helps you save money while still ensuring your family‚Äôs needs are met.

How This Mirrors Enterprise Procurement

At the enterprise level, procurement follows the same flow‚Äîonly it‚Äôs structured, automated, and scaled to handle greater complexity.

 

Personal Spend ExampleEnterprise Procurement Process
Classify expenses (e.g., groceries)Spend Classification: Categorize spend into goods and services like IT equipment, raw materials, or consulting services.
Analyze where you spend the mostSpend Analysis: Identify high-spend areas and uncover potential savings opportunities.
Search for vendorsSourcing: Conduct market research, invite bids (RFPs), and evaluate supplier capabilities.
Negotiate and select a vendorContracting: Negotiate terms (price, quality, delivery) and create legal contracts to formalize agreements.
Receive daily apple deliveryCataloging & Purchase Request: Maintain supplier catalogs for easy ordering and raise purchase requests as needed.
Receive invoice at month-endPurchase Order & Receipt: Issue purchase orders, confirm goods/services received, and match them with the invoice.
Pay the vendorInvoicing & Payment: Process, approve, and execute payments through financial systems.

Conclusion

Managing personal finances may seem worlds apart from enterprise procurement, but the underlying principles are remarkably similar. Both rely on classification, sourcing, negotiation, purchase, and payment to optimize spend while meeting essential needs.

The next time you shop for apples, you‚Äôre not just budgeting - you‚Äôre practicing procurement on a personal scale.

entry.title: Re: Extract selected data from very large Hana table usin...
entry.content:
What is the reason for the Data_Transfer transform? What is the where-clause being used?

Reason I ask is because normally, if you have Source --> Query (with where) --> ... the where clause gets translated into the source database syntax and pushed down automatically. Only the parts of the where clause the source does not support is executed in-engine. To proof that you can save the dataflow and use debug->display optimized sql.

The Data Transfer transform is used to break a dataflow into parts with an additional intermediate persistence between those.

With the provided information, my ideal dataflow would look like

Source --> Query --> Target

In the source turn on "enable partitioning".
In the dataflow properties set the degree-of-parallelism to the amount of partitions the source table has.

entry.title: Re: Time off Finland - accrual rules and best practices p...
entry.content:
Dear @NeeleshKamath

Thank you for answering my post. I will check the Ireland solution to control the length of the absence

As for the second issue, the point is that the accrual rule in best practices consists of deducting working days (e.g., 22 days per month) minus days of absence from the deduction amount (which could be 24 days), resulting in a negative number. We don't have the option to count the days in the month in "Deduction quantity" (Monday to Saturday) as we can do with the absence. 

That's why I was curious if any company managed to have this working correctly and automatically. I don't foresee any other workaround than having to create multiple absences "parental leave" - ones for the limit below 160 days (not disqualifying accrual) and others for the limit above 160 days (disqualifying for accrual), and duplicated as well because it could be a paid/unpaid period (for ECP replication). Of course, the administrator would need to select the correct absence manually, without any automatic calculation when the limit is reached.

What do you think of this option?

Thank you

Laura

entry.title: Re: Service Entry Sheet by value
entry.content:
Hello @lmarellano 

Service Entry Sheets are based on quantities. You cannot input SES by amount; the system calculates the value from the confirmed quantity multiplied by the PO price. For exact amounts, structure the PO with lines matching each target amount, or use Enhanced Limit (E) items with value caps and appropriate invoice tolerances.

SAP Help Portal-Manage Service Entry Sheets ‚Äì Lean Services

Useful SAP Documentation references

Here are the requirements for creating SES, including references to PO and the quantity drive. SAP Help Portal-Requirements for the Creation of Service Entry Sheets - Lean Services

Include Lean Services, utilising Enhanced Limit (E) for unplanned or value-capped services.  SAP Help Portal-Adding Lean Services

Set Tolerance Limits to allow small rounding variances. SAP Help Portal-Invoice with Variances

KBA: Tolerance checks for supplier invoices with Enhanced Limits (keys LD/LA, messages M8297/M8298). KBA 2841906 - Supplier Invoice tolerance checks for enhanced limits

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: GRC Tuesdays: Preventing Potential Fraud and Data Irregularities Across Ultra-High-Volume Operations
entry.content:
For today‚Äôs blog, I would like to thank my colleague Srinath Ganesan - Customer Advisory - Finance & Risk from SAP India. The content below comes from his work, and he deserves all the credits!

It has long been thought that fraud detection was only relevant in financial institutions ‚Äì banks, insurance, etc. But the truth is that companies in all industries can benefit from advanced analytics to detect anomalies, policy deviations and potential frauds in their supply, production, or delivery of products and services and improve their prevention and deterrence of adverse events.

An example here is Tata Steel, one of the world‚Äôs leading steel producers and a flagship enterprise of the Tata Group. Tata Steel Limited operates on a global scale, serving diverse industries across Europe, Southeast Asia, and other key markets. With a steadfast commitment to sustainability and innovation, the company plays a vital role in advancing infrastructure development while maintaining a robust commercial and industrial footprint worldwide.

To accelerate its growth strategy while ensuring regulatory compliance and maintaining operational integrity, Tata Steel focused on proactively detecting fraud, anomalies, and policy breaches in real time.

Indeed, despite robust ERP systems in place, supply chain vulnerabilities might persist, such as errors, maliciously modified documents or even fraudulent dispatches. These issues can erode operational integrity and financial performance of the organization and impair the achievement of business objectives.

The company therefore embarked on an implementation of an analytics platform designed to continuously monitor vast volumes of transactional data across key business functions, including procurement, finance, and supply chain operations.

 

Enter SAP Business Integrity Screening!

 

 By implementing SAP Business Integrity Screening, Tata Steel is looking to enhance its overall governance by screening a large volume of data across SAP and third-party systems and providing near-real-time alerts on exceptions.

Acting as a central anomaly detection engine integrated with source systems, SAP Business Integrity Screening helps monitor logistics operations and raise suspicious activities and even prevent unauthorized activities.

Providing end-to-end visibility, enabling compliance, finance and logistics team to track red flags, the solution raises repeated issues and provides access to a complete audit trail with evidence tied to exceptions for easier investigation. This results in enhanced fraud detection, improved compliance, and scalable monitoring.

 

So, what is SAP Business Integrity Screening?

 

Built on the established fact that organizations need to detect fraud, misuse, non-compliant or erroneous transactions earlier to reduce financial loss and risk exposure, but also on the fact that investigations teams receive far too many false positives so need to improve the accuracy of detection at less cost, SAP Business Integrity Screening has been designed to provide organizations the insights they need to guard business integrity and avoid suspicious transactions.

Some of its key capabilities include:

 

Design and determine the screening lists, analyze patterns, and define detection rules and models

Set-up the detection strategy through simulation and calibration

Detect by executing mass and/or real-time detection and stop anomalies or irregular transactions

Investigate alerts with efficient evaluation, qualification and remediation of issues

Analyze (key) performance indicators and create management reports

Of course, this is just a very high level description of the solution, but you can find more information in the dedicated page of the SAP.com portal: Business Integrity Screening for Fraud Detection | SAP

 And you can see it in action in the short recording: SAP Business Integrity Screening: Detect Suspicious Transactions

 

 

Customer Success Story

 

Should you wand to read more about the success story at Tata Steel and how SAP Business Integrity Screening enhances Tata Steel‚Äôs overall governance by screening large amounts of SAP software and third-party data and providing near-real-time alerts on exceptions, we are grateful that they have accepted to detail some of their challenges, expectations and achievements in an overview available here: Tata Steel: Preventing potential fraud and data irregularities across ultra-high-volume operations

 

See it in action at SAPinsider EMEA

 

And if you are interested in learning more about SAP Business Integrity Screening and seeing it in action, then have a look at the session AI in SAP GRC: Enhancing Compliance, Controls, and Risk Management that will be delivered by Rohit Hotwani ‚Äì Strategic Product Manager for SAP solutions for Three Lines (of Defense) at SAPinsider EMEA on October 1-3rd in Copenhagen.

entry.title: Business Strategy: Embracing an AI-First Mindset in Supply Chain Management, Logistics and Finance
entry.content:
As part of our strategic transformation initiatives, we are aligning our supply chain operations with an AI-First mindset to drive efficiency, agility, and data-driven decision-making across logistics and finance functions.

Strategic Objective

To leverage artificial intelligence as a core enabler for optimizing supply chain performance, reducing operational costs, and enhancing financial visibility and control.

Key Focus Areas

  1. AI in Logistics Operations
    • Predictive Analytics: Forecast demand, optimize inventory levels, and anticipate disruptions.
    • Intelligent Routing & Scheduling: Utilize machine learning to enhance delivery timelines and minimize fuel costs.
    • Automation of Warehousing: Implement AI-powered robotics and vision systems for faster, error-free operations.
  2. AI in Financial Supply Chain
    • Dynamic Pricing & Cost Optimization: Analyze market trends and supplier data to negotiate better terms.
    • Cash Flow Forecasting: Use AI models to predict receivables and payables with greater accuracy.
    • Risk Management: Detect anomalies and assess supplier financial health using AI-driven insights.

Implementation Roadmap

  • Phase 1: Assessment of current systems and identification of AI integration opportunities.
  • Phase 2: Pilot programs in logistics tracking and financial forecasting.
  • Phase 3: Full-scale deployment with continuous learning and model refinement.

Expected Outcomes

  • 15‚Äì20% reduction in logistics costs
  • Improved forecast accuracy by up to 30%
  • Enhanced decision-making speed and confidence across finance and operations

Call to Action

We encourage all stakeholders to actively participate in workshops and training sessions scheduled over the next quarter. Your insights and collaboration will be critical to the success of this transformation.

Let‚Äôs play together to build a smarter, more resilient supply chain powered by AI.

 

Key Focus Areas & AI Tool Examples

  1. AI in Logistics Operations
  • Predictive Analytics & Demand Forecasting:
    Tools:
    • Blue Yonder: AI-driven demand forecasting, inventory optimization, and scenario planning.
    • IBM Watson Supply Chain: Predicts disruptions and improves operational visibility.
    • FourKites: Real-time shipment tracking and predictive ETA using

.

  • Intelligent Routing & Scheduling:
    Tools:
    • Oracle SCM Cloud: AI-powered route optimization and logistics planning.
    • Manhattan Active Supply Chain: Uses machine learning for transportation and warehouse optimization.
  • Warehouse Automation:
    Tools:
    • Logiwa: AI for warehouse and inventory management, optimizing picking and packing.
    • Symbotic: Robotics and AI for automated warehouse operations

AI in Financial Supply Chain

  • Dynamic Pricing & Cost Optimization:
    Tools:
    • Coupa: AI-driven spend management and supplier negotiations.
    • SAP Ariba: Automates procurement and contract management with AI
  • Cash Flow Forecasting:
    Tools:
    • C3 AI: AI models for financial forecasting and risk management.
    • ThroughPut AI: Provides financial and logistics planning insights using advanced analytics
  • Risk Management & Supplier Analysis:
    Tools:
    • E2open: AI for supplier risk analysis and resilience management.
    • GigaSpaces eRAG: AI-driven simulations for risk and disruption planning

entry.title: SAP TM Freight Agreement Approval Workflow Process and Set Up.
entry.content:
Understanding Freight Agreement Approval

Freight agreement approval workflow is an organized process used to manage the review and authorization of freight contracts within a company. It usually includes collaboration between various departments such as procurement, legal, finance and logistics. The goal is to ensure that every part of the agreement complies with internal policies and meets all legal and regulatory standards.

Key Components of an Effective Freight Agreement Approval Workflow

  • Centralized storage for all freight agreements with easy access.
  • Automatic routing to relevant stakeholders based on set criteria.
  • Role-based access control to ensure proper review and approval
  • Real-time tracking and audit trails for full transparency.

Business Benefits of a Freight Agreement Workflow

  • Faster approvals with automated workflows and defined processes.
  • Better cost control by spotting rate issues and managing freight spend.
  • Improved compliance with legal and regulatory requirements.
  • Greater transparency and accountability with full audit tracking.
  • Stronger carrier partnerships through consistent agreement handling.

Freight Agreement Approval Workflow ‚Äì Configuration Steps 

  1. Org Level Configuration 
  2. Workflow Configuration 
  3. Freight Agreement Type Configuration 

1. Org Level Configuration 

  • All previously created organizational units are visible in the transaction code PPOME. 
  • Go to the organization unit, select your purchasing organization, and click Create. 
  • User IDs for the users who approve the freight agreement should be created in the backend. 
  • Create a position as Freight Agreement Approver. 
  • Select the Freight Agreement Approver option and click on Assign, then assign the user ID. 
  • Select the checkbox Head of Own Organizational Unit.

 

 

 

 

 

 

WF_APPROVER is the USER which will approve the Freight agreement.

 

2.Workflow Configuration 

Perform following steps to trigger a workflow for Agreement 

1.Goto transaction SWDD‚ÄØ 
2.Go to Workflow -> Other workflow/version ‚Äì then enter task WS71100

 

 

3.Go to Go To->Basic Data.

 

Again, Go To->Agent Assignment for task‚ÄØ

Click on Attributes and select General Task

 

Then click on Update Index icon to generate the index.‚ÄØ

Return to the previous screen by pressing F3 twice.‚ÄØ

4. Now click on the second step of this workflow.  

Go to Decision tab->Agents, select Organization unit and enter the Purchasing organization. So that it allows the users assigned to this purchasing organization to approve/reject the workflow.

Go to Control tab->Agent Assignment‚ÄØ 

 

     

Click on Update Index to generate index. 

 

 

Return to the previous screen by pressing F3 twice.‚ÄØ                                                           

5. Mark BUSINESS OBJECT as import parameter on Workflow container. Applicable from S4 CORE 106 onwards.‚ÄØ 

Select Workflow Container from the left side of the screen

 

Then select BUSINESSOBJECT from Element, and then set Import check box under Properties tab.‚ÄØ   

 

 

Then save and activate the workflow task.

 

Additional Tips:‚ÄØ

Make sure workflow RFC destination is created‚ÄØ

 

Workflow tasks status can be viewed on transaction SWI1‚ÄØ 

3.Freight Agreement Type Configuration 

Create a new freight agreement type for the freight agreement approval workflow. 
In the freight agreement type, select the Approval Workflow checkbox to enable workflow-based approval.

 

Test case 1: Confirm Approval Request 

Freight agreement approval notification: 
Go to the freight agreement and click on the Request Approval button to initiate the approval process. 

Once you click on Request for Approval, the lifecycle status of the freight agreement is updated to Awaiting Approval. 

 

An email notification will be sent to the respective users assigned to the purchasing organization.  

Check ‚ÄòMy Inbox‚Äô app or transaction SBWP to take action. 

 

Click on Confirm Approval Request ‚Äì the freight agreement lifecycle status will be updated to Released. 

 

Test Case2: Reject Approval Request 

If Approver wants to reject the freight agreement approval, click on the ‚ÄòReject Approval Check‚Äô.

 

If Approver wants to reject the freight agreement approval, click on the ‚ÄòReject Approval Check‚Äô.

The lifecycle status of the freight agreement is  ‚ÄòIn Process‚Äô. 

Note: if there are multi-level approval required that is also possible.

Conclusion

 

The Freight Agreement Approval Workflow plays a key role in controlling transportation costs and maintaining compliance with agreed terms. By automating the approval process,it reduces delays,minimizes errors,and improves transparency across departments. With features like tiered approvals, audit trails, and real-time notifications, it ensures that agreements are reviewed quickly and securely. Integrating this workflow into your logistics or SAPTM system strengthens supplier relationships and improves contract management. Ultimately, it helps teams make better decisions and aligns logistics operations with overall business goals.

entry.title: Request for Centralized Access to Historical Payment Advices

Thank you,
Siva Nagi Reddy

entry.title: EWM- Quantity Classification for Inbound Process
entry.content:
Introduction:

Quantity Classification in SAP  EWM is used to categorize stock based on its quantity ‚Äî typically distinguishing between full pallets and partial pallets. This classification allows the system to make more intelligent decisions when executing warehouse processes such as putaway and picking.

For example, a pallet that meets the defined full quantity threshold can be treated as a full pallet, while anything below that is considered a partial pallet. Based on this classification, different storage types, bin types, or strategies can be applied ‚Äî such as storing full pallets in Pallet storage Area and partial pallets in pick-face areas. By leveraging quantity classification, warehouse operations become more efficient and organized.

Quantity Classification for Inbound Process. The blog is about the classification of stock based on the quantity and different Putaway strategy based on it.

Business Requirement

  • Let's say a product is received and needs to be stored in the specific storage area based on the quantity received, we will use Quantity Classification.
  • For an example- if a Product X is received in its Base UoM which is Each and packed based on below

1 Each

1 Each

10 Each

1 Box

250 Each

1 Pallet

  • Now, based on the quantity we received system should automatically determine packaging specification and pack the products
  • Once packed system should determine the storage type like
    • Partial Pallet Storage (below 250 quantity as per our example)
    • Full Pallet Storage (= 250)

  • In above scenario, when we receive a product
    • Qty <250 it should be considered as a Partial Pallet and stored in ER75
    • Qty=250, it should be considered as a Full Pallet and stored in ER70

Configuration

  1. Warehouse Structure
    • Storage Type

ER70

ER75

  • Storage Bin

ER75

 
 

 

 

 

  • Activity Area

 

  • Bin Sorting

2. Quantity Classification

    • Define Quantity Classifications

                    Spro--> SCM EWM--> Cross Process Settings--> Warehouse Task--> Define Quantity Classification

 

  • Define Unit of Measure Attributes

           Spro--> SCM EWM--> Master Data--> Product--> Define Unit of Measure Attributes

 

3. Warehouse Process Type

    • Define WPT

 

  • Define PTDI

 

  • Determine WPT

 

4. STSS

    • Define STSS

 

  • Assign ST to STSS

 

  • Define PACI

 

  • Determine STSS

 

  • Sort Sequence

 

5. Storage Section Search Sequence

    • Define SS indicator

  • Maintain SSSS

 

6. Putaway Rules for Storage Bin

    • Define Bin Sections

 

  • Perform Bin Sectioning for Bin Type and HU Type

 

7. Packaging Specification

    • Pack Spec Group

 

  • Level Type

 

  • Element Type

 

  • Level Set

 

  • Allowed Packaging Material for Element Type

 

Master Data

  1. Material Master Data

2. Create Product Master and assign PTDI, PACI, SS-Indicator

3. Create Pack Spec

    • Full Pallet

 

  • Partial Pallet

4. Maintain Logical Conditions

    • Full Pallet: Qty = 250

 

  • Partial Pallet: Qty<250

5. Create Condition Maintenance

 

Testing

Create PO

  • Qty is 220
 

Create IBD in S4H

 

Process IBD in EWM

344 packspec.

Check Stock in Mon

Scenario 2: Full Pallet

Create PO

Qty is 250 which is Full Pallet

 

Create IBD in S4H

 

Process IBD in EWM

 

Check Pack

  • Pack Spec determined

 

Here Full Pallet Pack Spec is determined

Check Status in IBD in S4

 

 

Conclusion: 

So, based on Quantity Classification in SAP EWM, stock can be intelligently identified as Partial Pallet or Full Pallet, and corresponding Putaway Strategies can be configured. This enhances warehouse efficiency by ensuring:

  • Optimal space utilization,

  • Faster picking and replenishment,

  • Better inventory organization.

It aligns the warehouse processes with the business's operational needs, ensuring flexibility and scalability in handling diverse product types and volumes.

entry.title: Re: React BTP app throwing 403 token validation failed wh...
entry.content:
A 403 Forbidden error in an SAP BTP POST call means the request was understood by the server, but the client (your Fiori or BTP application or a tool like Postman) lacks the necessary authentication or authorization to access the resource.

This can be A common security measure for POST, PUT, and DELETE requests in SAP systems is CSRF protection. The server requires a special token to prevent cross-site request forgery attacks.

Symptom: Your GET request works, but the POST request fails with a 403 error.

Cause: You're not including the x-csrf-token header in your POST request.

Solution: You must first make a GET request to the same endpoint with the header x-csrf-token: Fetch. The server will respond with the token in the response header. You then include this token in the header of your subsequent POST request.
