entry.title: The Ultimate S/4HANA Guide for Logistics and Inventory Management
entry.content:
Part 1: The Ultimate S/4HANA Guide for Logistics and Inventory Management

Page 1: Welcome to Inventory Management in SAP S/4HANA

Hello and welcome! üëã Whether you're an end-user, a Key User, a consultant, or just curious about SAP, this guide is for you. We're going to embark on a journey through the core of any business: managing what you own. The original documents you provided described a classic, custom-built process for tracking inventory between an external system and an older SAP version. Today, we'll translate that into the powerful, standardized, and streamlined world of SAP S/4HANA.

Our goal is to demystify Inventory Management (IM) and Extended Warehouse Management (EWM). We'll explore how to track stock from the moment it arrives until it ships to a customer, and most importantly, how to ensure your system's data perfectly matches what's physically on your shelves.

Core Concepts You Must Know

Before we dive in, let's get familiar with the language of SAP inventory:

  • Plant: A physical location where goods are produced, stored, or services are provided. Think of it as your factory or distribution center site (e.g., Plant 1010 in Berlin).
  • Storage Location: A specific area within a Plant where stock is physically kept. A single plant can have multiple storage locations, such as RM01 for Raw Materials, FG01 for Finished Goods, and QI01 for Quality Inspection.
  • Warehouse Number: Used in EWM, this represents an entire physical warehouse complex. It's a level above Storage Location and is linked to a Plant/Storage Location combination.
  • Stock Types: This defines the usability of your inventory. The three main types are:
    • Unrestricted-Use: Good to go! Ready to be sold, used in production, or shipped.
    • Quality Inspection (QI): The stock is physically present but is undergoing inspection. It cannot be used until it's cleared.
    • Blocked Stock: Physically present but should not be used. This could be due to damage or other issues. It is not considered part of your available inventory.
  • Special Stocks: This refers to stock that doesn't technically belong to you or is designated for a special purpose. We'll touch on these key types:
    • K - Vendor Consignment: The stock is in your warehouse, but the vendor still owns it. You only pay for it when you consume it.
    • E - Sales Order Stock: This inventory is specifically reserved for a single customer's sales order. It cannot be sold to anyone else.
    • O - Stock Provided to Vendor: Your raw materials that you've sent to a subcontractor for processing.

The Modern Interface: SAP Fiori Launchpad fiori

Forget complex codes and cluttered screens. The SAP S/4HANA user experience is primarily through the Fiori Launchpad. It's a web-based portal with "apps" (tiles) for every task, just like on your smartphone. It's role-based, so you'll only see the apps relevant to your job. We will reference Fiori apps throughout this guide. For traditionalists or where Fiori isn't available, we'll also provide the classic SAP GUI transaction codes.

Page 2: A Tale of Two Systems: IM vs. EWM

SAP S/4HANA offers two primary ways to manage inventory, and choosing the right one is crucial.

Inventory Management (IM)

IM is the bedrock of SAP logistics. It's perfect for businesses that need solid, real-time inventory quantity and value tracking at the Plant and Storage Location level.

  • When to use IM:
    • Simple warehouses or stock rooms.
    • When you primarily need to know the quantity of a material in a specific area.
    • When complex, bin-level warehouse activities like directed putaway or picking strategies are not required.
  • Key Transactions/Apps: Post Goods Movement (MIGO), Transfer Stock, Manage Stock.
  • The Bottom Line: IM tells you what you have and where (at a high level).

Extended Warehouse Management (EWM)

EWM is the powerhouse. It's a comprehensive solution for managing complex warehouse operations with precision. It controls every micro-movement of a product inside the warehouse walls.

  • When to use EWM:
    • Large, high-volume distribution centers.
    • When you need to manage stock at a granular Storage Bin level (e.g., Aisle 1, Rack 2, Shelf 3).
    • When you require advanced functionality like wave picking, slotting, labor management, or value-added services.
  • Key EWM Concepts: EWM introduces its own objects like Warehouse Tasks (instructions to move goods), Handling Units (pallets/boxes with unique IDs), and complex process strategies.
  • The Bottom Line: EWM tells you exactly where everything is and orchestrates the most efficient way to move it.

The custom interface described in the source documents was a bridge to an external WMS. In the S/4HANA world, EWM is the native SAP solution that often replaces such external systems, providing seamless integration. For the rest of this guide, we'll focus primarily on the IM Physical Inventory process, which is the direct modern equivalent of the core process in your documents, and we'll introduce EWM concepts where relevant.

Page 3: The Foundation: Master Data is King üëë

You can't manage what you haven't defined. Master data is the static, core data that describes your products, business partners, and locations. Getting this right is non-negotiable.

The Material Master

This is the single source of truth for every product you buy, make, or sell.

  • Fiori App: Manage Product Master Data
  • SAP GUI: MM01 (Create) / MM02 (Change) / MM03 (Display)

Key Views for Inventory:

  • Basic Data 1 & 2: General information like description, Base Unit of Measure (e.g., PC, KG), and Material Group.
  • Purchasing: Data for buying the material, like Purchasing Group and Order Unit.
  • MRP 1, 2, 3, 4: Data for planning production and procurement, such as MRP Type and Lot Size.
  • Plant Data / Storage 1 & 2: Plant-specific data, including Storage Conditions and Shelf Life. This is where you extend a material to a specific plant and storage location.
  • Warehouse Management 1 & 2: If using EWM, this view contains warehouse-specific parameters.
  • Accounting 1 & 2: Crucial for valuation! This includes the Valuation Class (which links the material to a G/L account in Finance) and Price Control (Standard or Moving Average).

Practical Exercise: Create a Raw Material

  1. Open the Manage Product Master Data app.
  2. Click Create.
  3. Enter a Material Number (e.g., RM-1001), select Material Type ROH (Raw Material), and choose the required views (start with Basic Data, Purchasing, Plant Data, and Accounting).
  4. Fill in the mandatory fields on each screen:
    • Basic Data: Description (Aluminum Frame 30x30), Base Unit of Measure (PC).
    • Purchasing: Purchasing Group (001).
    • Plant Data: Assign it to your Plant (e.g., 1010).
    • Accounting: Valuation Class (3000 for raw materials) and set an initial price.
  5. Click Save. You've just created your first material!

Page 4: Knowing Your Partners: The Business Partner

In S/4HANA, the old concepts of "Customer" and "Vendor" are unified into a single object: the Business Partner (BP). A single BP can have multiple roles.

  • Fiori App: Manage Business Partner
  • SAP GUI: BP

Key BP Roles for Logistics:

  • General Role (000000): Basic data like name and address. This is always the starting point.
  • FI Vendor (FLVN00): The role that connects the BP to the Company Code for financial postings (invoices, payments).
  • Supplier (FLVN01): The role that connects the BP to the Purchasing Organization for procurement activities (purchase orders).
  • FI Customer (FLCU00): The financial role for the sales side.
  • Customer (FLCU01): The sales role for processing sales orders and deliveries.

To create a fully functional supplier, you must create the BP with the General Role first, then extend it by adding the FI Vendor and Supplier roles.

Practical Exercise: Create a Supplier

  1. Open the Manage Business Partner app and choose to create a new Organization.
  2. In the Create in BP role field, start with Supplier (FLVN01). The system will automatically guide you to create the General role first.
  3. Enter the supplier's name (e.g., Global Tech Components), address, and language.
  4. Navigate to the Company Code section and click Create. Assign your Company Code (e.g., 1010) and enter a Reconciliation Account (this links Accounts Payable to the General Ledger). This creates the FLVN00 role.
  5. Navigate to the Purchasing section and click Create. Assign your Purchasing Organization (e.g., 1010) and enter the Order Currency (e.g., EUR). This completes the FLVN01 role.
  6. Click Save. Your supplier is now ready for business!

Page 5: The Lifeblood of Inventory: Goods Movements

Goods movements are the heart of IM. Every time stock enters, leaves, or moves within your plant, a goods movement is recorded. This creates a Material Document as a record of the movement and, in most cases, an Accounting Document to reflect the financial impact.

The primary tool for this is the Post Goods Movement app, which is the Fiori equivalent of the classic MIGO transaction.

  • Fiori App: Post Goods Movement
  • SAP GUI: MIGO

Goods Receipt (GR): Welcoming Stock

A goods receipt is any movement that increases your warehouse stock.

Common Scenario: GR for a Purchase Order (PO)

This is the most common GR. You've ordered goods from a supplier, and they have now arrived.

"How-To" Instructions:

  1. Open the Post Goods Movement app.
  2. In the top-left dropdown, select Goods Receipt. In the second dropdown, select Purchase Order.
  3. Enter your Purchase Order number in the field on the right. The system will pull in all the details (material, quantity, etc.).
  4. Go to the "Where" tab for each item and confirm the Plant and Storage Location where the goods are being received.
  5. Crucially, check the Stock Type field. You can receive it directly into Unrestricted-Use, or, more commonly, into Quality Inspection if the material requires a check.
  6. Check the "OK" checkbox for the items you are receiving.
  7. Click Post.

Result: The system creates a Material Document. If the material is valuated, an Accounting Document is also created, typically debiting the Inventory account and crediting the GR/IR (Goods Receipt/Invoice Receipt) clearing account. Your stock quantity is now updated in real-time.

Financial Integration Point: The link between the material movement and the correct G/L accounts is made automatically via the Valuation Class on the Material Master and configuration in a process called Account Determination (transaction OBYC). This is a cornerstone of SAP's integration.

Page 6: More Goods Movements: Issues and Transfers

Goods Issue (GI): Sending Stock Out

A goods issue is any movement that decreases your warehouse stock.

Common Scenario: GI to a Cost Center

This is used for consuming materials internally, for example, issuing office supplies or maintenance spares.

"How-To" Instructions:

  1. Open the Post Goods Movement app.
  2. In the top-left dropdown, select Goods Issue. In the second dropdown, select Others. The system will default to Movement Type 201 (GI for cost center).
  3. On the "Material" tab, enter the Material number.
  4. On the "Quantity" tab, enter how much you are issuing.
  5. On the "Where" tab, enter the Plant and Storage Location you are issuing from.
  6. A new tab, "Account Assignment", will appear. Enter the Cost Center that will bear the cost of the consumed material.
  7. Click Post.

Result: A Material Document and an Accounting Document are created. The Accounting Document will credit the Inventory account (reducing its value) and debit a consumption expense account linked to the cost center you entered.

Transfer Posting: Moving Stock Around

A transfer posting is a change in a stock's status. It could be a physical move or a logical one.

Common Scenario: Storage Location to Storage Location Transfer

Physically moving goods from a receiving area to a main storage area.

"How-To" Instructions:

  1. Open the Post Goods Movement app.
  2. Select Transfer Posting and Others. Movement Type 311 is the standard for this.
  3. On the "Transfer" tab, enter the Material, the issuing Plant, and the "From" Storage Location.
  4. In the "Destination" section, enter the "To" Storage Location.
  5. Enter the quantity and click Post.

Result: Only a Material Document is created. Since the stock still belongs to the same plant and has the same value, there is typically no financial impact for a simple storage location transfer.

Page 7: S/4HANA Customizing for Inventory Management

For consultants and key users, understanding where the "magic" is configured is essential. Customizing is done via the SPRO transaction in the SAP GUI or the Manage Your Solution app in S/4HANA Cloud (CBC - Central Business Configuration).

Key SPRO Menu Path: SPRO -> Materials Management -> Inventory Management and Physical Inventory

Here you can configure:

  • Plant Parameters: Set plant-level settings for inventory.
  • Number Assignment: Define number ranges for Material Documents, Physical Inventory Documents, etc.
  • Movement Types: This is a critical area! You can copy standard movement types (like 311) to create custom ones (like the 901, 902 from the source documents). This allows you to assign different G/L accounts or properties to specific business processes.
    • Example: You could create movement type Z01 as a copy of 701 (GI Inventory Difference) and name it "Inventory Loss - Damage" and Z02 as "Inventory Loss - Theft". This allows for more granular financial reporting on inventory write-offs.
  • Goods Issue / Transfer Postings: Configure settings for specific movement types.
  • Physical Inventory: Settings for tolerances, posting rules, and default values.

A Word on Scope Items: In the S/4HANA Cloud world, much of this is pre-configured in what are called Scope Items. A scope item is a pre-defined business process (e.g., 1MR for Physical Inventory). Activating a scope item brings in the necessary Fiori apps and baseline configuration. This accelerates implementation significantly. The processes we are discussing align with standard scope items like BML (Goods Movement), 1MR (Physical Inventory), and BMH (Initial Stock Upload).

Page 8: The Moment of Truth: The Physical Inventory Process

This is the core business process that the original custom development was built to support. Physical inventory (or "stock-taking") is the process of counting every item in a storage location and comparing that physical count to the quantities listed in the SAP system. The goal is to identify and correct any discrepancies.

In S/4HANA, this is a fully standardized, end-to-end process. It replaces the entire flow of creating a file, FTP'ing it, and running custom programs.

Why Do We Do This?

  • Accuracy: To ensure the stock data in SAP, which drives planning (MRP) and sales promises, is 100% accurate.
  • Financial Compliance: To correctly state the value of inventory on the balance sheet. This is often a legal or regulatory requirement for annual financial reporting.
  • Process Improvement: To identify underlying issues. Are there high levels of scrap? Is there theft? Are receiving processes flawed?

Types of Physical Inventory

  • Periodic Inventory (Annual Count): The "big bang" approach. The entire warehouse or plant is shut down, and everything is counted at once. This is what the source documents primarily describe.
  • Cycle Counting: A more modern approach. Instead of counting everything at once, you count small, specific areas or materials continuously throughout the year. For example, high-value "A" items are counted monthly, "B" items quarterly, and low-value "C" items annually. This minimizes disruption.
  • Continuous Inventory: Stock is counted continuously as part of daily warehouse operations.

The S/4HANA process supports all of these methods. We will walk through the Periodic Inventory process step-by-step.

Page 9: Step 1 & 2: Creating and Preparing the Count

The first step is to tell SAP what you are going to count. You do this by creating a Physical Inventory Document. This document acts as a worksheet, listing all the materials that should be in a specific location and freezing their "book inventory balance" at the moment of creation.

Step 1: Create Physical Inventory Document

  • Fiori App: Create Physical Inventory Document
  • SAP GUI: MI01 (for a single document) or MI31 (to create documents for a whole plant in batch)

"How-To" Instructions:

  1. Open the Create Physical Inventory Document app.
  2. Enter the Plant and Storage Location you want to count.
  3. Enter the Planned Count Date.
  4. You can set various flags, for example:
    • Posting Block: This is important! If checked, it prevents any goods movements (receipts, issues) for the materials in this document while the count is active, ensuring the book balance doesn't change mid-count.
    • Freeze Book Inventory: This captures the current stock level for later comparison.
  5. On the next screen, enter the list of Materials you want to count in that location. If you leave it blank, the system will include all materials that have stock in that location.
  6. Click Save. The system generates a unique Physical Inventory Document number.

Step 2: Print the Inventory Document

Once created, you need to provide a count sheet to the warehouse team.

  • Fiori App: Print Physical Inventory Documents
  • SAP GUI: MI21

This app generates a printable list showing the material number, description, and a blank space for the counter to write down the physical quantity. For a "blind count," you would not print the expected system quantity on this sheet.

Page 10: Step 3 & 4: The Physical Count and Data Entry

Step 3: The Count üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

This step happens outside of SAP. The warehouse team takes the count sheets and physically counts the materials.

Best Practices:

  • Use teams of two: one person counts, the other verifies and records.
  • Mark counted areas clearly to avoid double-counting or missing sections.
  • Ensure clear instructions are given on how to handle different units of measure (e.g., count individual pieces, not boxes).

Step 4: Enter the Count Results

After the physical count is complete, the results must be entered into SAP.

  • Fiori App: Enter Physical Inventory Count
  • SAP GUI: MI04

"How-To" Instructions:

  1. Open the Enter Physical Inventory Count app.
  2. Enter the Physical Inventory Document number from Step 1, the Fiscal Year, and the Count Date.
  3. The system will display the list of materials from the document.
  4. For each material, enter the Quantity that was physically counted in the corresponding field.
  5. If you counted zero of something, you must explicitly enter "0" and check the "Zero Count" (ZC) box. This tells SAP you looked for it and confirmed it's not there, as opposed to just skipping it.
  6. Click Save.

The count is now recorded in SAP, but no financial postings have occurred yet! At this stage, you have simply entered the data. The book inventory quantity is still the same as it was before the process started.

Page 11: Step 5 & 6: Analyzing Differences and Posting

This is the most critical part of the process, where you review the discrepancies and make the final financial update. This two-step approach of analyzing before posting is a direct standard equivalent to the "confirmation of differences" step requested in the original technical specifications.

Step 5: Analyze and Recount (If Necessary)

Before making any financial postings, you must review the differences.

  • Fiori App: Manage Physical Inventory Documents
  • SAP GUI: MI20 (Display List of Differences)

"How-To" Instructions:

  1. Open the Manage Physical Inventory Documents app.
  2. Search for your Physical Inventory Document.
  3. The app provides a clear overview, showing:
    • Book Quantity: The frozen quantity from SAP.
    • Counted Quantity: The number you just entered.
    • Difference Quantity: The variance (gain or loss).
    • Difference Value: The financial value of the discrepancy.
  4. Decision Point: You can now analyze this list. Sort by the highest difference value. Are there any huge, unexpected variances?
    • If a difference seems unreasonable (e.g., a count of 5 for an item with a book quantity of 5000), it's likely a counting error.
    • In this case, you can select the item and trigger a recount. This sends the warehouse team back to count that specific item again. The process then loops back to Step 4 for that item.

Step 6: Post the Inventory Differences

Once you are satisfied that the count is accurate and the differences are real, you can post them. This is the step that updates the inventory quantities and values in the system.

  • Fiori App: Post Physical Inventory Document
  • SAP GUI: MI07

"How-To" Instructions:

  1. Open the Post Physical Inventory Document app.
  2. Enter your Physical Inventory Document number.
  3. The system will display the same list of differences.
  4. Enter a Reason for the movement if required (e.g., Scrap, Counting Error).
  5. Click Post.

The Magic Happens: When you post, SAP does two things simultaneously:

  1. It creates a Material Document that adjusts the stock quantity.
    • For a stock loss, it uses Movement Type 702.
    • For a stock gain, it uses Movement Type 701.
  2. It creates an Accounting Document that reflects the financial value of the change.
    • For a loss, it will Credit the Inventory G/L Account (decreasing its value) and Debit an Inventory Differences Expense G/L Account.
    • For a gain, it will Debit Inventory and Credit Inventory Differences.

Your stock is now officially adjusted, and the Physical Inventory Document is closed.

Page 12: The Full Process Flow: Periodic Inventory

Here's a visual summary of the entire end-to-end standard process:

  1. Create PI Document (Create Physical Inventory Document)
    • Input: Plant, Storage Location, Materials
    • Output: Physical Inventory Document Number
  2. Print & Distribute (Print Physical Inventory Documents)
    • Input: PI Document Number
    • Output: Printable Count Sheets
  3. Physical Count in Warehouse
    • Action: Manual counting process
    • Output: Completed Count Sheets
  4. Enter Count (Enter Physical Inventory Count)
    • Input: PI Document Number, Counted Quantities
    • Output: Count is saved in the PI Document
  5. Review Differences (Manage Physical Inventory Documents)
    • Input: PI Document Number
    • Action: Analyze variances. Decide to Recount or Post.
  6. Post Differences (Post Physical Inventory Document)
    • Input: PI Document Number
    • Output: Material Document, Accounting Document. Stock levels and values are updated.

This single, standard flow replaces the need for the custom programs, tables, and complex file transfers described in the source documents. It is more robust, fully integrated, and provides a complete audit trail.

Page 13: The Big Bang: Initial Stock Balance Upload

What if you are implementing SAP S/4HANA for the first time? You need to load your initial stock balances from your old system. The source documents describe a custom program (ZRMM0501) for this "stock takeover." The modern, standard approach is far superior.

There are two primary methods for this:

  1. SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit (The Recommended Method)
  2. Manual Upload via Goods Movement App (For Small Data Sets)

Method 1: SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit (LTMC)

This is the official, powerful, and recommended tool for any large-scale data migration into S/4HANA.

  • Fiori App: Migrate Your Data ‚Äì Migration Cockpit

Process Overview:

  1. Create a Migration Project: You start by creating a project in the app, linking it to your target system.
  2. Select the Migration Object: SAP provides pre-built migration objects for almost every data type. For this task, you would select Material - Stock Balance.
  3. Download Template: The cockpit provides a pre-formatted Microsoft Excel (XML) file template. This template contains all the necessary fields for uploading stock.
  4. Fill the Template: This is the data preparation step. You would extract the stock data from your legacy system (like the spicwrklg.csv file from your documents) and populate the template. Key columns will include:
    • Material Number
    • Plant
    • Storage Location
    • Quantity
    • Base Unit of Measure
    • Stock Type (Unrestricted, Quality Inspection, Blocked)
    • Batch Number (if applicable)
    • Special Stock Indicators and relevant numbers (e.g., Vendor for consignment stock).
  5. Upload and Process: You upload the completed file back into the Migration Cockpit. The tool then guides you through a series of steps:
    • Prepare: System checks the file structure.
    • Validate Data: Checks your data against SAP's logic (e.g., does the material exist in that plant?).
    • Convert Values: Maps any legacy values to S/4HANA values.
    • Simulate: A "dry run" that simulates the posting without actually creating any documents. This is a crucial step to catch errors.
    • Execute Import: The final step. The cockpit processes the file and posts the stock balances in the system.

Advantages of the Migration Cockpit:

  • Standardized and Guided: The process is clear and reduces the risk of error.
  • Pre-built Validations: Catches data errors before they hit the system.
  • High Volume: Designed to handle thousands or millions of records efficiently.

Page 14: Initial Stock Upload (Continued)

Method 2: Manual Upload via Post Goods Movement

For a very small number of materials or for training purposes, you can perform the initial stock upload manually. This method directly posts the stock using special "initial entry" movement types.

  • Fiori App: Post Goods Movement
  • SAP GUI: MIGO

Key Movement Types for Initial Upload:

  • 561: Initial entry of stock balances - Unrestricted-Use
  • 563: Initial entry of stock balances - Quality Inspection
  • 565: Initial entry of stock balances - Blocked Stock

"How-To" Instructions (using Movement Type 561):

  1. Open the Post Goods Movement app.
  2. Select Goods Receipt and Others.
  3. In the Movement Type field on the right, manually enter 561.
  4. Now, simply enter the details for each material you want to upload:
    • Material: The material number.
    • Quantity: The initial stock quantity.
    • Where: The Plant and Storage Location.
    • Partner: (Optional) You can enter the Vendor from whom the stock was originally purchased.
  5. You can add multiple lines for different materials in the same transaction.
  6. Click Post.

Result: For each line, the system creates a Material Document and an Accounting Document. The accounting entry for a 561 movement is a Debit to the Inventory G/L Account and a Credit to an Initial Stock Upload clearing account. This clearing account is later reconciled by Finance as part of the go-live cutover activities.

Which Method to Choose?

  • Go-Live / Large Project: Always use the Migration Cockpit.
  • A few missing items after go-live / Testing: The manual MIGO method is quick and easy.

Page 15: Introduction to EWM Physical Inventory

If your company uses Extended Warehouse Management (EWM), the physical inventory process is similar in principle but more granular and robust, as it operates at the Storage Bin level.

Key Difference: The IM process asks, "How many of Material X are in Storage Location 0001?" The EWM process asks, "What is in Bin A-01-01? And what is in Bin A-01-02?" You count the bins, not just the material.

EWM Physical Inventory Process Flow:

  • Fiori Apps: Create Warehouse Physical Inventory Document, Enter Count Results for Warehouse
  • SAP GUI: /SCWM/PI_CREATE, /SCWM/PI_COUNT, /SCWM/PI_PROCESS
  1. Create EWM PI Document: You create an inventory document for a range of storage bins, a specific storage type, or for a particular product across the entire warehouse.
  2. Print & Count: The warehouse team receives a list of bins to count. They go to each bin and count everything inside it.
  3. Enter Count in EWM: The count results are entered into the EWM system against the specific bin.
  4. Analyze Differences in EWM: You can see discrepancies at the bin level. For example, the system thought Bin A-01-01 had 10 PCs, but the count found 12 PCs.
  5. Post Differences in EWM: When you post the difference in EWM (/SCWM/PI_PROCESS), the system first adjusts the stock quantity within the EWM module. It corrects the bin stock.
  6. Post Differences in IM (Synchronization): EWM then automatically sends the financial difference up to the Inventory Management (IM) level. This is usually done through a background process called a queue (qRFC). This triggers the creation of the Material Document (Mvt 701/702) and the Accounting Document in the S/4HANA core, just like in the IM process.

Why the two-step posting? This separation allows the warehouse to continue operating with corrected stock levels in EWM immediately, while the financial posting can be managed separately by the inventory control team, ensuring a clean separation of duties.

Page 16: Beyond Inventory: The Integrated Supply Chain

Inventory management doesn't exist in a vacuum. It's part of a larger, integrated process. The data we've been managing is used across the entire supply chain.

Handling Unit Management (HUM)

For many warehouses, tracking individual items is not enough. They manage goods on pallets, in boxes, or in totes. Handling Unit Management (HUM) allows you to assign a unique license plate number to each of these HUs.

  • An HU is a combination of materials and packaging materials.
  • All inventory movements can then be performed by moving the HU number, and SAP automatically knows all the contents inside. This massively speeds up operations.
  • EWM is inherently designed to work with Handling Units.

Outbound Processing: Order to Cash

The accurate inventory we've maintained is crucial for the sales process.

  1. Sales Order Creation: When a sales order is created (Create Sales Orders - VA01), the system performs an Availability Check (ATP) against the unrestricted stock we've been managing. If the stock is available, the order is confirmed.
  2. Outbound Delivery: An Outbound Delivery (Manage Outbound Deliveries - VL01N) is created as a shipping request. This reserves the stock.
  3. Picking: In an EWM-managed warehouse, a Warehouse Task is created to tell a worker which bin to pick the material from.
  4. Post Goods Issue (PGI): This is the final step in shipping. When the truck leaves, you post the goods issue. This is a critical integration point:
    • MM: Stock quantity is reduced.
    • FI/CO: The value of the inventory is credited, and the Cost of Goods Sold (COGS) is debited.
    • SD: The status of the delivery is updated, allowing for invoicing.

Transportation Management (TM)

For businesses with complex shipping logistics, Transportation Management (TM) comes into play. TM helps plan and optimize freight.

  • Deliveries are consolidated into Freight Units.
  • Freight Units are planned onto Freight Orders (representing a truck or shipment).
  • TM helps with carrier selection, freight tendering, and calculating freight costs, which can then be settled.

This deep integration‚Äîfrom a stock count in the warehouse to the final financial reporting‚Äîis the core strength of SAP S/4HANA.

Part 2: The Ultimate S/4HANA End-to-End Test Plan

Page 17: Introduction to Your Test Mission

Welcome, testers! This plan is your guide to validating the S/4HANA logistics and inventory processes. Your mission is to follow these test cases step-by-step to ensure the system works as expected. This plan is designed for all roles and will take you through a realistic, day-in-the-life business flow.

Your Role: Depending on your background, you might be an End User, a Key User, or a Consultant. The goal is the same: execute the steps, observe the results, and compare them to the "Expected Result."

Test Environment & Prerequisites:

  • You have access to an SAP S/4HANA system with the Fiori Launchpad.
  • You have a user ID with the necessary authorizations (e.g., Warehouse Clerk, Inventory Manager, Purchaser).
  • The basic organizational structure (Company Code, Plant, Storage Location, Purchasing Org) has been configured.

Let's begin! üöÄ

Page 18: Test Cycle 1: Master Data Foundation

Objective: Create the core master data required for all subsequent logistic processes. Without this, nothing works!

Test Case

Step

Fiori App / GUI

Test Data

Expected Result

TC1.1

Create a Raw Material

Manage Product Master Data / MM01

Material: TG-RM-01 Desc: Titanium Gear Casing Type: ROH UoM: PC Views: Basic, Purch, Plant, Acct

Material TG-RM-01 is created successfully. You receive a "Product TG-RM-01 created" message.

TC1.2

Create a Finished Good

Manage Product Master Data / MM01

Material: TG-FG-01 Desc: Assembled Gearbox T-200 Type: FERT UoM: PC Views: Basic, Sales, MRP, Plant, Acct

Material TG-FG-01 is created successfully.

TC1.3

Create a Supplier

Manage Business Partner / BP

Name: Precision Parts Inc. Role: Supplier (FLVN01) Address: 123 Main St, Tech City

A Business Partner number is created. You can see the basic address data.

TC1.4

Extend Supplier to Company Code and Purchasing Org

Manage Business Partner / BP

BP: Use BP from TC1.3 Company Code: 1010 Purch. Org: 1010 Recon Acct: (e.g., 160000) Currency: EUR

The BP is successfully extended. The Company Code and Purchasing segments are visible and saved. The supplier is now ready for procurement.

TC1.5

Create a Customer

Manage Business Partner / BP

Name: Global Industrial Corp. Role: Customer (FLCU01) Address: 456 Commerce Ave, Metro

A new Business Partner number is created for the customer.

Page 19: Test Cycle 2: Procure-to-Pay & Initial Stocking

Objective: Procure a raw material from the supplier and perform an initial stock upload for other materials, simulating both daily operations and a system go-live. This cycle directly replaces the legacy process for initial stock takeover (ZRMM0501).

Test Case

Step

Fiori App / GUI

Test Data

Expected Result

TC2.1

Create Purchase Order

Manage Purchase Orders / ME21N

Supplier: BP from TC1.3 Material: TG-RM-01 Qty: 100 PC Plant: 1010

A Purchase Order is created with a unique number.

TC2.2

Post Goods Receipt for PO into Quality Stock

Post Goods Movement / MIGO

Action: Goods Receipt, Purchase Order PO Num: From TC2.1 SLoc: RM01 Stock Type: Quality Inspection

A Material Document is created. Using the Stock - Single Material app, you can see 100 PC of TG-RM-01 in Quality Inspection stock for Plant 1010 / SLoc RM01. An Accounting Document is also created.

TC2.3

Post from Quality to Unrestricted

Post Goods Movement / MIGO

Action: Transfer Posting Mvt Type: 321 Material: TG-RM-01 SLoc: RM01 Qty: 100 PC

A Material Document is created. The stock for TG-RM-01 moves from the Quality Inspection column to the Unrestricted-Use column in the Stock - Single Material app. No new accounting document is generated.

TC2.4

Perform Initial Stock Upload (Manual)

Post Goods Movement / MIGO

Action: Goods Receipt, Others Mvt Type: 561 Materials: - TG-FG-01, Qty 50, SLoc FG01 - TG-RM-01, Qty 250, SLoc RM01

A Material Document is created. An Accounting Document is created. The stock levels for both materials are immediately increased in Unrestricted-Use stock. This validates the standard process for initial data loads.

Page 20: Test Cycle 3: The Annual Physical Inventory

Objective: Validate the complete, standard end-to-end Physical Inventory process. This cycle is the modern replacement for the entire custom interface (1IMM01/4IMM01) described in the source documents.

Test Case

Step

Fiori App / GUI

Test Data

Expected Result

TC3.1

Create PI Document

Create Physical Inventory Document / MI01

Plant: 1010 SLoc: RM01 Materials: TG-RM-01 Flags: Set Posting Block

A Physical Inventory Document is created with a unique number. The book balance for TG-RM-01 should be 350 PC (100 from PO + 250 from 561).

TC3.2

Enter Count Result (Stock Loss)

Enter Physical Inventory Count / MI04

PI Doc: From TC3.1 Material: TG-RM-01 Counted Qty: 345 PC

The count of 345 is successfully saved to the PI Document. No stock movements have occurred yet.

TC3.3

Analyze Difference

Manage Physical Inventory Documents / MI20

PI Doc: From TC3.1

The screen clearly shows: - Book Qty: 350 - Counted Qty: 345 - Difference Qty: -5 - The financial value of the 5 missing pieces is displayed.

TC3.4

Post Difference

Post Physical Inventory Document / MI07

PI Doc: From TC3.1

The difference is posted. Three key things happen: 1. The PI Document status becomes "Counted, Posted". 2. A Material Document is created with Movement Type 702 (GI for PI difference). 3. An Accounting Document is created, crediting inventory and debiting the inventory difference account. The stock for TG-RM-01 is now 345 PC.

TC3.5

Re-run with Stock Gain

Repeat steps TC3.1 to TC3.4 for material TG-FG-01 in SLoc FG01 (book is 50). This time, enter a count of 52 PC.

All steps should work as before, but the final posting will use Movement Type 701 (GR for PI difference). The final stock will be 52 PC, and the accounting entry will be the reverse of TC3.4.

 

Page 21: Test Cycle 4: Advanced Scenarios & Validations

Objective: Test more complex scenarios based on the error checks and special cases from the original test documents. This ensures the robustness of the standard process.

Test Case

Step

Fiori App / GUI

Test Data

Expected Result

TC4.1

PI with Zero Count

Create a new PI document for SLoc RM01. This time, include a material that exists in the system but has zero stock in that location.

Create PI Doc / Enter Count

When entering the count, enter 0 and check the "Zero Count" box. The system should accept this. When posted, no material or financial documents are generated for this item, as there was no difference. This confirms proper handling of zero-stock items.

TC4.2

Data Validation: PI for Non-Existent Location

Attempt to create a PI Document for a material that has not been extended to the storage location you are trying to count.

Create PI Document / MI01

The system should issue a standard error message like "Material TG-RM-01 not maintained in storage location FG01" and prevent the creation of the PI Document. This validates that standard SAP checks replace the need for custom program logic to check for data consistency.

TC4.3

PI for Special Stock - Vendor Consignment

1. Use Post Goods Movement (Mvt 501 K) to receive 20 units of a material as vendor consignment stock. 2. Create a PI Document, making sure to select the Vendor Consignment stock special type. 3. Count and post a difference.

MIGO, MI01, MI04, MI07

The process works successfully. The stock difference posting correctly adjusts the consignment stock level. No accounting document is generated, because you don't own the stock. Instead, a liability to the vendor is created/adjusted. This validates the handling of special stock K.

Page 22: Test Cycle 5: Order-to-Cash & Financial Reconciliation

Objective: Complete the business cycle by selling the finished good. This demonstrates the integration of our accurate inventory data with the Sales and Distribution (SD) and Finance (FI/CO) modules.

Test Case

Step

Fiori App / GUI

Test Data

Expected Result

TC5.1

Create Sales Order

Create Sales Orders / VA01

Customer: BP from TC1.5 Material: TG-FG-01 Qty: 10 PC

A Sales Order is created with a unique number. The system confirms the availability of the 10 pieces based on our current stock level.

TC5.2

Create Outbound Delivery

Manage Outbound Deliveries / VL01N

SO Num: From TC5.1

An Outbound Delivery document is created.

TC5.3

Post Goods Issue

Post Goods Issue / VL02N

Delivery Num: From TC5.2

A Material Document is created. The stock of TG-FG-01 is reduced by 10 PC. An Accounting Document is created, crediting Inventory and debiting Cost of Goods Sold (COGS).

TC5.4

Create Billing Document

Create Billing Documents / VF01

Delivery Num: From TC5.2

An invoice (Billing Document) is created. A final Accounting Document is generated, debiting the Customer's Accounts Receivable and crediting a Revenue account.

TC5.5

Financial Reconciliation

Display Line Items in General Ledger / FAGLL03

G/L Account: Your inventory account. Company Code: 1010

You can view the full history of postings to the inventory account: the initial upload (561), the PI loss (702), the PI gain (701), and the goods issue for sale (601). The final balance reflects the true financial value of your current stock.

This concludes the test plan. By successfully completing these cycles, you have validated a complete and integrated end-to-end business process in SAP S/4HANA, from master data to financial reporting. Great job! üëç

entry.title: Re: 'Manage Cancellations' app to cancel quantity confirmations
entry.content: @antoniomasseretti  what about create a custom pod plugin to do what you need? For instance we are calling a custom ODATA from SAP DM just by define it inside manage service reigstry as new service but you can also use standard SAP odata! Of course you must define a destination inside your SAP BTP in order to reach SAP through SAP Cloud Connector.

entry.title: Re: Risk is now available in SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
Absolutely an advantage to have also this standard project management functionality as a function/instrument within SAP Cloud ALM! :-).

So far, I don't see though a risk matrix within the analytics app based on the common risk rating of impact an probability.

Do I overlook something? Do you know anything about this advanced function? (I haven't spotted it so far on the SAP Cloud Roadmap)

Note: What I have seen is the functionality of downloading the list into XLS
